André Menegotto
    MSCA Researcher Fellow
    
      
        
      
      
        
      
      
        
      
      
        
      
      
        
      

    
  
  
    I am a Marine Macroecologist interested in understating the diversity patterns in the global ocean, quantifying biodiversity knowledge gaps, and assessing anthropogenic impacts on marine ecosystems. I work extensively with global biodiversity data, R programming, spatial analyses, computational simulations, and synthesis techniques.
    I am currently a MSCA Fellow at the University of Sheffield (2024-2026), collaborating with the MNCN-CSIC. Specifically, I am working with Tom Webb and Joaquín Hortal on the MarineGaps project, which aims to map sample coverage for marine species and propose solutions to reduce or account for the spatial bias in big biodiversity databases.
    Previously, I was a Juan de la Cierva Fellow in Spain at the Universidad de Madrid (2022–2024) and a Research Fellow in Brazil at the Universidade Federal de Goiás (2019–2022). For more details about my previous research, please visit the Publications page. If you are interested in discussing any of the topics mentioned above, feel free to contact me at: a.menegotto [at] sheffield.ac.uk.

AquaMaps in R
If you want to download the modeled distribution of marine species from the AquaMaps web site in R using the ‘raquamaps’ package, I corrected some bugs and updated the nativerange function.
I am not the original developer of the package, so you can use this updated function by installing my forked version, as shown below:


# Install the raquamaps package from my github with this command
library("devtools")
install_github("AndreMenegotto/raquamaps")

# Choose a species and download its map ("Mugil liza" as an example)
library(raquamaps)
native_range_df <- nativerange(latinname = "Mugil liza")

# Rasterize the output
library(terra)
cells <- vect(native_range_df$hspec, geom = c("Center.Long", "Center.Lat"), crs = "EPSG:4326")
r <- rast(res=.5, vals=0, crs="EPSG:4326")
map <- rasterize(cells, r, field = "Overall.Probability")
map <- project(map, "+proj=robin")

# Plot the map
library(rnaturalearth)
land <- ne_download(scale = 110, type = "land", category = "physical", returnclass = "sv")
land <- project(land, "+proj=robin")

plot(land, col="grey80", border="transparent", axes=F)
plot(map, add=T, plg=list(size=c(.75,.5)))
plot(graticule(360, 180, "+proj=robin"), labels=F, lwd=.75, add=T)
plot(graticule(60, 45, "+proj=robin"), labels=F, lwd=.5, lty=2, add=T)



Environmental suitability of Mugil liza according to AquaMaps

Educational outreach for kids
Together with the amazing Milena Diniz, I wrote an article for kids explaining the concept of citizen science and showing how to use the iNaturalist platform to explore the biodiversity around us.
The article, titled “Digital Nature”, is available in Portuguese for subscribers of ‘Ciência Hoje das Crianças’.
